docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- President Obama made the case Wednesday for slowing the rapid growth of the national debt while retaining core Democratic values, proposing a mix of long-term spending cuts, tax increases and changes to social welfare programs as his opening position in a fierce partisan budget battle over the nation's fiscal challenges. After spending months on the sidelines as Republicans laid out their plans, Mr. Obama jumped in to present an alternative and a philosophical rebuttal to the conservative approach that will reach the House floor on Friday. Republican leaders were working Wednesday to round up votes for that measure and one to finance the government for the rest of the fiscal year.

headline.main: Taking On G.O.P., Obama Unveils Debt Relief Plan

docs.abstract: Pres Obama proposes mix of long-term spending cuts, tax increases and few changes to social welfare programs as his opening position in fierce partisan budget battle over national debt; says proposal would cut federal budget deficits by cumulative $4 trillion over 12 years, compared with deficit reduction of $4.4 trillion over 10 years in Republican plan; photo; chart (M)

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Jackie Calmes, John Harwood and Thom Shanker contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: The economist Eric Toder has pointed out that the largest corporate tax loopholes also happen to be among the most politically popular. They include the tax breaks for new machinery and for research and development. The policies don't seem like corporate giveaways -- though, to some extent, they are -- as much as they seem like efforts to create jobs.

headline.main: The Largest Tax Breaks for Individuals

docs.abstract: Looking at the three largest tax breaks for individuals.
docs.snippet: Looking at the three largest tax breaks for individuals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Style: I liked the way Obama made a case for government at the beginning. I liked the way he accused Republicans of pessimism, of abandoning a hopeful vision of America. Good that he went after the Ryan plan -- and good that he went after the cruelty of that plan. If you ask me, too many percentages. Oh, and whichever speechwriter came up with "win the future" should be sent to count yurts in Outer Mongolia.

Changes to Medicare may seem ever more likely, with President Obama expected on Wednesday to talk about ways to lower the deficit and eke savings out from entitlement programs. He is speaking just a week after Republicans laid out a proposal that would privatize Medicare, the insurance program for people over 65.
docs.abstract: What should be done to fix Medicare to control costs?
